pros: Extremely gifted and passionate colleagues (more so than most competitors) who believe strongly in the work they do. Highly ideologically motivated team. Genuinely inclusive and respectful workforce that values everyone's opinion. Excellent internal and external communications. The folks who stay with CARE long-term truly are married to their jobs! If you don't mind that or have competing priorities, then there are lots of excellent opportunities to travel and grow with the organization.
cons: Chronically under-staffed and over-worked. Organizational culture accepts and rewards little-to-no work-life balance. Very high staff turn-over. Poor team building and cohesion overall. (Some limited efforts are made, but few people have time to participate due to the demanding workload.) Weak operational and administrative systems and protocols for such an established and large organization. Departments and units are very siloed, resulting in many redundancies. Inefficient on many levels, including high frequency of meetings. Also very frugal! CARE maintains a super low overhead by regularly externalizing costs to its own employees, especially those costs relating to travel and event costs. Benefits are fine, but not particularly impressive relative to other NGOs.

review_title: Great organization, great mission, wrong leadership
pros: Noble mission, amazing, talented colleagues globally, so much enthusiasm and devotion everywhere! I would love to work for CARE again but they need some level of overhaul.

review_title: Making the world a better place with one CARE resignation at a time

And lets add 5 more meetings to the week regarding the same discussion that we've had for the last year and still haven't seen any results. Nonprofits are slow but things would move a lot quicker if we'd stop doing the same thing over and over again expecting different results. Management says they want feedback but they seem too overwhelmed to have any time to act on any. The turnover is insanely high but the onboarding process is atrocious which leads to people deciding they want to leave before they've even settled in to their position. review_title: Good workplace culture but poor systems and pay
pros: Smart, kind and passionate colleagues. The organization makes much more impact and saves more lives than most of its kind. People are generally helpful and collaborative. The organization is focused on de-colonization and localization, and practices (not just preaches) progressive and human rights-based values. At least on my team, colleagues are respectful of a work-life balance and working remotely.
cons:
Overall, the organization does a disservice to itself by splitting the work into humanitarian vs. development settings. This means two people working on, say, food security, might never collaborate or learn from each other, if they are working in different settings. Countries don't neatly divide into either development or emergency situations- they are fluid, and some are mostly stable with an emergency in just one part of the country. So why does CARE still insist on taking this approach? It causes confusion, competition, territorialism, and duplication of efforts.

Specifically:

1) Because the international structure is confederated (most countries' CARE offices are independent) there is very little cohesion, communication/collaboration between technical teams or across countries, and a lot of duplication of efforts. It is hard to manage quality when each country is more or less left to its own devices, but still represents that CARE brand.

2) The monitoring and evaluation systems are just terrible. CARE needs a modern digital platform to track, analyze, visualize and report data. I am a data person used to working with numbers, but I cannot make sense of CARE's system and it's difficult to pull a single statistic from all the confusing databases and dashboards. The M&E staff are prickly and not very helpful.

3) I adored CARE's HR until I had a baby. I spent my ENTIRE pregnancy and four months after the birth of my child trying to figure out how much maternity leave I could take. I got conflicting and incorrect information from each HR person I spoke with. Part of this is because the United States has a patchwork of parental leave polices that differ across states, but the HR leave representative was unwilling to read a two-page document about the paid leave available where I live. I spent probably 150 hours on the phone/email/internet trying to get the leave I was entitled to. In the end my boss intervened and gave me an extremely generous leave.

4) CARE pays less than most other NGOs. I don't mind because my position is perfect for me, but it means we can't recruit highly qualified staff in country. The quality of work from most countries I've supported has been very poor compared to other NGOs where I've worked. This is partly a casualty of the decolonization effort. Staff in the Global North can never lead but may only support. Often that means a sacrifice in quality.

5) Despite 2 years of visible backlash about the Communication team's unethical marketing and fundraising practices, they continue to depict suffering people in undignified and harmful ways to get donations. This has turned off some partners and donors we wanted to work with, particularly pop up ads asking for donations when, say, a donor comes to our site looking for information about our programs and approaches.

review_title: Retaliatory environment, duplicative U.S. leadership roles, wasteful organization
pros: The mission attracts hard-working, skilled experts committed to the values CARE exhibits, along with the star-studded external conferences and other awareness-raising events. There are opportunities to get involved in different work groups and special initiatives, which may offer needed distractions from other internal frustrations or challenges.
cons:
Below-market pay compared to peer organizations
Minimal protections for employees
A lack of transparency on salary bands for positions
Non-sensical (practically non-existent) merit increase policy

CARE protects its leadership and the communities it serves but not its employees. There are absolutely no accountability standards at this organization. Staff in leadership roles are allowed to exhibit poor professional behavior, including retaliating against staff who report them, without any recourse.  Annual performance reviews aren't even evaluated by HR nor archived at all because there is no authentic and comprehensive merit increase policy.

What donors and others will find beneath the surface of CARE is a culture of overworked, underpaid, and - depending on the manager - under-appreciated staff who are the lifeblood of this organization. Meanwhile, there is exorbitant spending on public relations to generate more revenue to create unnecessary and duplicate leadership roles. The layers of leadership at this organization are ridiculous.

If you decide to work here, commit to a specific time frame for your tenure and then take your talents to a more authentic place with accountability standards for everyone and protection measures for employees, as well as better pay and benefits.

pros: It's a great cause - helping to end poverty around the world. Most people are smart and passionate about what they do and are fantastic to work with. Benefits are very strong for a nonprofit organization.
cons: Senior Management lacks the ability to effectively and competently run the organization.  During my four years there, we went through five staff restructurings, two of which were organization-wide and included large layoffs due to financial troubles (not economy-related, but mismanagement).  They keep shuffling things around below them in the hopes that it will make things run better, when in fact, they should be looking at themselves to see how things could be improved starting at the top.  In the last round of layoffs, they made attempts to involve the staff in the decision making process, but that only resulted in higher anxiety and lower staff morale for everyone. pros: Although I do believe that development/humanitarian organizations are quickly becoming obsolete, this organization has a wonderful mission and passionate employees who are some of the most amazing and intelligent people on earth.
cons:
Executive leadership is a  bloated, top-heavy, incompetent, self-serving mess.  Financial mismanagement, abysmal diversity, and non-existent accountability.  There have been many rounds of layoffs over the past year with no end in sight, and somehow, leadership has been completely unaffected.

There are few opportunities or pathways for advancement - in many roles, you can expect to be a lifer with no promotion or salary change, even when you consistently perform and exceed goals. 

Where is all the money going? I'm no financial savant, but I'd glance in the direction of executive salaries - it's obscene.  Maybe if the CEO took a moment away from planning her next Senate or gubernatorial race, she'd better understand how terrible a job she's doing and how ineffective her leadership team is.

review_title: One wonders about the true priorities of CARE USA's management team
pros: Good benefits, unquestionably honorable mission, great field staff.
cons:
In the past 2-3 years, the Executive Management Team (reporting to the CEO) has doubled in size.  This top-heavy suite includes highly paid floaters with opaque roles, a surge of Washington DC Democratic Party stalwarts, and the expected tossed salad of new ideas, initiatives and champions.  A propensity for flashy initiatives that play well in the media but deliver questionable impact for the people CARE serves, and a disquieting disregard for fiscal sensibility belies a management team driven by short-term rewards – just enough career burnishing to bridge a return to politics with the winds shifting left.

With a few exceptions, the next layer of senior management doesn’t inspire higher confidence.  The latest backstabbing catty tactic or in-your-face unprofessional outburst pepper the daily musings of the hapless around the water cooler.  As such, turnover has been accelerating and this is key – it is turnover of valued, skilled employees.  Recruiting fresh new talent is one thing – exchanging high-performing people with less-than-competent replacements is a sure-fire way to accelerate the rot from within.

There continue to be highly talented & industrious individuals working at CARE USA.  Sadly, these individuals are becoming isolated within a core culture sorely in need of honest self-assessment.

review_title: If you're smart, motivated and results driven, CARE is NOT for you.
pros:
The most inspiring mission you could ever ask for.
Terrific partners in the corporate and philanthropy world.
Decent pay for a nonprofit. But don't expect to advance or ever get a raise.
cons:
Lack of talent - people who don't do their jobs and aren't accountable for results. 
There's so much internal politics and people who aren't necessarily qualified to do the job but have been at the organizations for years and decades. It's so sad to see such an amazing organization be so self destructive. 

Co-workers get too territorial because they are worried about losing their jobs since they do nothing all day.

There is absolutely NO room for career growth or even a chance to try something new.

pros: Economic and social programs are helping women and children in many countries (outside of the US).
cons: Complete dysfunction in the Atlanta, GA office. Individuals are constantly under prepared to do the work that is expected (lack of communication, lack of resources, withheld information, etc). Clear expectations are rarely set. Many staff members work in fear of not meeting their goals. Getting things done quickly is more important than done correctly and with quality. There is a huge lack of accountability across the organization. You are not properly prepared to handle uncomfortable or unfamiliar situations in countries you are required to travel to. There is absolutely not enough focus on the overall wellness of staff members. BURNOUT. There is a tremendous amount of focus on pleasing tenured leaders who Speak the Loudest. Some of the most senior leaders have their own agenda to push; rather than promoting the success of their team members. Many of the promotions, new hires, and transitions are based on favoritism instead of the most qualified. Unfair internal practices exist that are extremely embarrassing. So much more could be said. CARE USA is the worst employer I have ever worked for in my career.

review_title: Good exposure to programmatic work in global health however definite management issues (not just at higher levels)
pros: Great exposure to extremely important work. CARE has a solid history working for a great cause. People are passionate and good to work with. Room for learning new things.
cons:
Poor professional etiquette in managing people - leads to a loss of integrity and is often reflected by a lack of confidence and trust in management (not only higher-level executive management). 

Any pride you have to work with as part of an organization that does this great work ends up being tainted by the effects of poor management and many unfulfilled words.

Seems to have serious issues retaining talent and nurturing growth of employees. 

Middle management comes across insensitive at times to their employee's situation aggravating already high-levels of job insecurity and anxiety. Overall, CARE USA has had better days, would recommend looking to organizations that can offer a more stable working environment and greater sensitivity to better weather these already uncertain times.

pros: CARE USA is a great brand and is respected for the work that they do for women and girls. I also like Helene Gayle. She's been a great leader for the organization.
cons: The downside had to do with HR's senior managers. They're not the competent and it can be frustrating at times. Because they're no outside people to communicate your frustrations to and hopefully get results. I worked in HR and there were always drama as well as poor management by the senior managers in that department. It was also felt and communicated by employees who did not work within HR. They really need to rehab their HR department, starting with the Senior VP of HR and her managers.

review_title: Heartbreaking to see the org fail time after time
pros: CARE has a lot of pros. There's good time off, schedule flexibility, and a descent benefits package. Smart, dedicated people work at CARE.  The mission is excellent and CARE seems to excel at it's work abroad.
cons: The main challenge is that leadership has failed.  CARE's leadership can't seem to get the organization on firm footing and has basically thrown in the towel, hoping to save it by slimming down to next to nothing by 2020.  That means, if you aren't already working at CARE, don't start now.  You're likely to find yourself in a temporary position, even if it's not advertised that way.  Most of the old timers at CARE USA are gone, voluntarily or not, along with all their ideas, knowledge, and non-profit know how.  Those who have stepped in to replace them aren't meeting the monumental challenges before them, which would be hard for anyone to do.

review_title: Tragic to see the state of this NGO
pros: It's CARE - formerly one of the best international NGOs to work for! The staff that do remain are great and a pleasure to work with - both at HQ and in the field.
cons: Constant reorganization. Develop a clear vision of the future and work toward that. What is it that CARE wants to be? Humanitarian response? Focused on women and girls? Focused on poverty reduction? Instead, numerous consulting firms are brought in to revamp this vision. It's sad - they split up technical areas to then only merge them back a year later. Or, they lay people off only to rehire them in a few months because they've lost all the capacity in a certain area. If they would map out what they wanted, they could eliminate the back and forthing that erodes staff confidence in management.

review_title: 10 years of service to an organization that didn't deserve it.
pros: Wonderful mission that has helped countless people across the world for decades.
cons: Two words: Senior Management.  They are nearly incompetent at running a large business, they squander money (the result being at least 5 rounds of non-strategic layoffs), they spend most of their time traveling at donor expense, they provide no real leadership, and they cover up VERY sever problems within the board and executive leadership (the sort of problems that would have resulted in major PR issues and reporters asking questions).

review_title: Roller coaster through a tough economy
pros: The mission is what invigorates a lot of people about CARE USA. Reading reports on progress and projects is uplifting and hopeful, even if you're not in the field; when you read the reports, you know you're doing good work.  There are dedicated experts in both the field work, programatic planning, and support services.  CARE Is dedicated to a core set of values.
cons: There was a lot of forced fun when I worked there during a down economy. It didn't help anyone to be forced into "fun activities."  The bureaucracy was difficult to navigate at CARE.  Most of senior management shoulder blame for problems, but that begs the question, why are there so many senior management team members resigning?

pros: The coworkers were approachable and really helpful.
cons: I was put under a supervisor who would shout at us like children and slam laptops. It was a highly stressful job due to the high demand of hours but it is no excuse to act unprofessionally and subject your subordinates to abuse. The higher manager of the department refused to handle this supervisor probably because of the deadlines but the result is that the turnover of candidates under this supervisor is high and the ones that remain are only there for their own benefit in the time being.

review_title: You need to have a good supervisor
pros: There are good supervisors if you are lucky enough, free coffee every morning, year end holidays, annual staff event..
cons: People get promotions based on performance only. They do not systematize the holistic individual. You will see people with bad behaviors grow and become powerful in the organization. This does not motivate staff and many valuable talents leave because of this.  I do not generalize, it may be different in offices elsewhere.

review_title: Go to CARE only if you want to be a lifelong employee of non-profits. Excellent place to intern in too.
pros: I liked the fact that CARE USA allows for a good work-life balance. They have a business casual feel to them, inspite of being a very professional organization. They care to make a difference and they so.
cons: The only downside to work in a non-profit is that if/when you want to branch away to a "for profit" organization, their perception is that potential employees have not "cut their teeth".

pros: Committed staff, good programs, tries to do a little of everything. People work hard and CARE has a name that stretches back years and years.
cons: Leadership is very weak and has time and again demonstrated a lack of listening and a lack of direction. Decision making is opaque. The past 3-4 years there has been huge turnover and many staff have either been let go or left on their own--the organization is drifting.

pros: Mission. Quality of country office programming. Dedication of people.
cons: HQ is a disaster. CEO still not capable; can't make decisions; chaotic and it is getting worse all the time. CEO does not appear to genuinely appreciate the people that get the work done or care to know anything about how it gets done. Constant change without a thoughtful path or helping employees see how to be part of the change. Treated like a cog. Also: No accountability at the executive level and spending money like it's growing on trees.

pros: CARE can be a great place to work depending upon department and manager.Benefits, time off, 401K.
cons: Work life balance nearly destroyed, used to be much better. The indecisiveness, inappropriate behavior by some colleagues, and outdated technology presents some obvious challenges. There is little to no career advancement, and often times a dead end in a position.  Over 5 rounds of layoffs and furlough have created a low morale and distrust with many employees, management, to the board. Constant reorganization and vision change of course has created a culture of instability and fear in various areas.

pros: The mission.  The possibility to help people around the world lift themselves out of poverty is what attracts anyone to CARE.  On your best day, you can make a difference in the lives of people who desperately need a hand up.
cons: CARE has not invested in its people.  It rarely promotes from within, leaving staff feeling as if their contributions are not valued.  While salaries are fair, salary increases once inside the organization are very hard to come by.  Poor managers are not held accountable, and promotions are rarely based on management ability.

cons: New leadership over the last 2 years has resulted in total confusion about organizational identity and mission, huge deficit, lack of accountability...a runaway train.  The best staff are leaving, the worst are staying, and the leaders either don't understand their jobs or are not willing to take responsibility.

review_title: Good place but unstable with financing.
job_title: Senior Technical Advisor in Atlanta, GA
pros: The work environment to me was casual, flexible hours, caring people and my supervisor was never there so I had autonomy to be creative n my work.
cons: Leadership slow on decision making, excessive spending with no innovations. A lot of sending in travel and not using technology to save donors' funding. Executive Management in some areas always traveled and did not have second in command so not vision was set.

pros: Big, exciting, compelling vision — this was my ultimate drive during my entire stay with the organization
cons:
I don’t relish revisiting the cons but I want to supplement the previous negative review. 
So here’s what’s killing the org:

1. Poor org structure and role distribution; ambiguous policies and IT processes

2. No definite career development plan. Promotions are usually offered upon resignation. Go figure.

3. Alarming attrition rate; yet still no retention plans (up until I left the org, not sure now)

4. Flexible work option (remote work, shift schedule) is selective, and criteria for eligibility is not explained nor justified. Certain staff members are allowed and some are not. Favoritism and politics are abundant.

5. The Director and HR (yep, Human Resources) are prone to rationalizing unethical behavior by supervisors.. Rather than addressing a recurring attitude problem, they let it slide. I’ve heard supervisors getting sassy and condescending most of the time and getting away with it just because. Heck, I’ve even heard the HR talk down a fellow HR member via email, and in person. Yikes!

The list goes on. I drain myself just by typing about it. I had a few good months with the company but overall, I can’t find a reason to go back or even recommend them to others. I’ve seen A LOT of great talents leave the company, and the company didn’t seem to CARE (pun, yup).

CARE pays relatively well.
cons: Sometimes the good efforts and performance of country and project staff often shadow the work overload they put up with to get the high standard results.

review_title: A very positive experience when I first started, but increasingly disappointed with the way the NGO is run
pros:
Competitive salaries and benefits, although these will probably be trimmed down in the future (and that makes sense for an organization dedicated to eradicating poverty and social injustice). 

Enjoyable, casual office environment. Most of my colleagues and supervisors over the years were easy-going with a good sense of humor. Most of them were very hard workers.  I always felt I could offer critical feedback to my superiors--speak my mind--without being concerned about the effect on my job security. 

If you stand out as a "star" employee, CARE will offer you excellent professional development opportunities (training, workshops, travel, temporary duty assignments...)
cons:
I was very satisfied at CARE when I first joined over 10 years ago, and inspired by the thinking that was happening in the organization at both HQ and field levels. But now CARE is struggling to find itself, to identify its priorities and relevance, and to remain focused and competitive in the changing aid environment. Too many changing priorities and approaches; not enough results and applied learning; field staff increasingly frustrated and burned-out. 

I worked many years in a Country Office that would almost *never* walk away from a funding opportunity, even if the funds weren't aligned with the Office's strategic directions, and even if we didn't have the right human resources for the project -- there was always a way to justify going after the money. I know of several examples of employees being promoted and/or acquiring a lot of power within the organization/their teams largely because of their ability to raise funds and tell a good story to CARE's donors, in spite of serious weakness in their people-management skills, respect of diversity, and integrity.  

Any talk of improving work-life balance is not taken very seriously at field level. There is an unspoken expectation that employees will work nights and weekends, and the more capable and available you are, the more CARE will ask of you. I would have felt a lot better about putting in the extra hours had I felt that by doing so I was helping contribute to greater program impact and accountability to "beneficiaries". But most of those hours were spent chasing funds and introducing new initiatives from HQ.

All that said, I found there to be a lot of variability between Country Offices (some places better run than others and by more skilled leaders). However the changes that CARE is undertaking from the highest levels of the organization down make this a challenging time.
